utterances: Without giving the story away, I was still left thinking at the end.
No matter what happens, Cassie and Julia will always be important to each other.
Might be years before they recognize it again but they'll always be important to each other.
And I think that relationships of that intensity, whatever they are and however they end - they define us and shape us and mark us.
And those people remain important to us even if we never see them or speak to them again.
And that's true, obviously, with romantic relationships, too.
You know, you might feel it's not possible to stay in touch with somebody you used to love passionately.
But whatever time you spent together was formative and is with you always.
Claire Messud - her novel, ""The Burning Girl."" Thank you so much for being with us.
From NPR News, this is NEWS & NOTES.
Today, we have a lot of news from Africa.
There are new Sudan sanctions on Africa update, and Aisha Conteh rebuilding her father's hospital in Sierra Leone.
But first, let's kick things off with headlines.
Today, we start at the famed Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
The executive director of MIT's Center for Biomedical Innovation has resigned in protest over what he considers racial politics at the school.
His colleague, James Shirley, held a 12-day hunger strike in February when MIT refused him tenure.
Shirley said he was denied because he too is black.
And Douglas resigned because he says school officials broke a promise to reconsider Shirley's case.
But MIT says it made no such promise.
Our next headline takes us to Jackson, Mississippi.
A jury has been picked and the trial is underway for 71-year-old James Ford Seale.
The reputed Ku Klux Klansman is on trial for kidnapping and conspiracy.
Back in 1964, he allegedly helped a group of whites kidnap and murder two black teens, Henry Dee and Charles Moore.
The teens were tied alive to engine parts and dumped into the Mississippi River.
They were later found accidentally by investigators looking for the three slain civil rights workers: Schwerner, Goodman, and Chaney.
Charles Moore's brother, Thomas Moore spoke with NEWS & NOTES in January to explain why his brother's case went to so cold for so long.
My mom went to the sheriff department and he told her a lie.
We didn't have anyone to go to being from a poor family.
We didn't have money to solicit help from attorneys or things like that.
So they're all saying we just have to eat it up.
But Thomas Moore never gave up and the FBI reopened his brother's case in 2005.
James Ford Seale has pled not guilty and denies being involved with the Klan, and in the deaths of Moore and Dee.
If you make a list of the most harrowing places in the world, you might begin with Iraq.
Next, we could add North Korea, and then maybe throw in the Balkans in the 1990s.
And that's basically the resume of Ambassador Christopher Hill.
He has a new memoir out called ""Outpost: Life On The Frontlines Of American Diplomacy."" Welcome to the program.

I want to discuss the book and the arc of your career, but I have to ask, as a former ambassador to Iraq early in the Obama administration, whether you look at what is happening in Iraq and feel a sense of futility?
Well, certainly, when you look at Iraq today, you feel a sense that you had when you were living there that this is a huge problem.
It didn't just start yesterday, and it certainly didn't just start with the election of Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki, difficult person that he is.
He's the - I should just clarify, he's the Iraqi leader whose sectarian policies of ruling sort of were believed to led, in part, to the rise of ISIS.
Lefroff (ph), no, that would be three Fs.
I was going to say it like something you find on a piece of clothing, like an adornment.
And your last one is road, R-O-A-D, as in dog.
You did a very fine job.
